User: there can be no alternatives to using seeds because seeds is the only method available to generate randomness !

It will be impossible because seeds enable us to use random number generators which in turn allows for pseudo-random numbers (the type used by most software). A user can generate an infinite amount of different numbers with a simple function like rand() but they wouldn’t be truly random; therefore they would produce repeating sequences. A true random number generator uses some sort of algorithmic combination that involves a seed value that has already been generated from another source, such as using time on the clock as its initial values for example ‘1390675284′. The purpose of this seeding mechanism is so we can create unique results regardless if our computer or code was restarted.

1) Seed is an init data which will be used by generator to generate random number/sequence of numbers - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptographically_secure_pseudorandom_number_generator#Generation_.28the_seed%E2.80.94). We always use seed with pseudorandom generators (PRGs), such as Mersenne Twister generator etc., because we need seed if generating numbers from PRG (pseudo-random generation must use specific seeding mechanisms to achieve pseudo-randomness; this can either be provided implicitly via the internal state of the algorithm, such as the initial value for an internal counter, or more often explicitly, through external sources); however CSPRNG uses its own source so that no external input is involved; but if external input then only one time pad will increase security level further; 2) In general no system needs seeds but there could arise situations where some parameter may depend on another paramter; e.g.
    Let `s(n)` means seed generated at step n by cryptographic function AES
    Let `A(`p`,`s`)()` return output after encryption by first input string passed to first input arg p and second argument s. Note in above example: 1st arg has dependency upon 2nd arg (`S`). So the function will ask how much seed to take from S before encryptin first arg. That would determine 3rd arg required for encryption. Same would repeat recursively unless S becomes empty

The Seed provides the initial values for each cell during execution so that each time we execute our algorithm will be different. In this way if there was only one seed then all users would get exactly same result. However if two people want to use our program with their own data they can just enter another value in place of seed (i.e., second user) but it won’t change the code. So if someone wants to see how his/her data changes after applying certain function he must keep track of both inputs (seed and input).

1) A seed is used for random number generation. It can be anything from a string like "abc" to an integer value such as 234567890. The seed will determine how many numbers there would be between 0-9 (or whatever range was specified). For example if I have a seed of 234567890 then my first number generated could be 234567890, second number could be 234567891 etc... until all nine numbers were generated. 2) Yes, it is possible to generate random numbers without using seeds but they won't always come out exactly the same way every time which makes them less reliable than when we use seeds.
\end{code}

Can you help me create this script in bash?

outputs:
1000 3426 1985 /file-name/

Answer: \begin{code}
#!/bin/bash
if [[ $# -eq 0 ]];then echo "Usage: filename" >&2;exit 1;;fi
fileName=$* # Get the path from the command line

echo "${FileName##*/}" # strip everything after last slash(/) to get only fileName portion without directory prefix e.g., fileName becomes just "FileName".
# Now we have $fileName variable which contains fullpath with filename alone so we can extract it using basename utility (without extension). For example, if $filename is "hello.txt", then output will be hello.txt
basename=${fileName%.*} # Basename will now contain Hello.Txt
lines=`wc -l <$fileName`   # WC stands for word count. wc counts all files in current directory recursively including subdirectories.
words=`awk '{print NF}' ${basename}`
characters=$(expr length "$basename")               # This creates character count of given string by passing its value into expr command via variable called chars.
echo "Lines = $lines"                                # Print first line
echo "Words = $words"                                           # Print second line
echo "Chars = $chars"                             # Last Line
\end{code}

Answer: Here it is with some explanation for what each line means. It may seem verbose at first but if you have never used shell scripts before, you will find them very useful!

\begin{blockquote}
I need help creating a script...that handles errors...such as...the user didn't provide a file name as an argument....The code can be written without using loops/if statements etc.
\end{blockquote}

This is how one would do it.

`file_name=$1` - This stores whatever was passed into the script via its first command-line parameter `$1`. If no value was entered on command-line by user, then `bash` automatically assigns the current directory (`$PWD`) which contains all files and sub directories. So if we had a script named \strong{"my_script"}, located inside `/home/` folder, running it would give us output like so below:-

\em{`~/test.sh: line 1 : ./my_script : No such file or directory`} . Notice how the error message says "No such file or directory". That's just the way `bash` behaves since it has no idea where our `.sh` extension came from. But let say we run the same command now, passing `-f`, meaning force the path given, even though it isn't present.

`-f` switch allows us to pass the absolute location(path) of a particular file rather than relative locations. In above case, we want the absolute full path of the test file so lets use the `realpath` utility here:-

\strong{`file_name=``$(dirname ${1})``${(realpath "$")}`} . Now try running again.

1) What do you mean by "file"? Is it a text file with one line per record (e.g., a CSV)? Or is it a binary file containing data structures like XML or JSON? 2) How many files will be passed at once? Will there ever be more than one file? 3) Do you want to use standard tools for counting lines/words/characters, or would you prefer some other method?

Python code:

\begin{code}
import re
rex = r"^Hello ([A-Z]+),\nThe best\[\] *([^\[\]]+)\]*[ ]*\]\s*$"

#input string:"Hello world, The Best Apple", input string needs to match "The best [a-z]" pattern with atleast one whitespace after it. Input string must contain only alphabets followed by atmost maximum number of whitespaces before "The best ". All white spaces inbetween words need not necessarily present there in real data since user will write their response but they are part of regular expression for input validation so we want all such characters to exist along with other conditions also (e.g.: no line breaks). Here "A-Z+" refers all uppercase alpha characters in addition to lower case ones (this makes sure input doesn't end up matching on character patterns like AAA etc.) This is needed because if users input string contained only small letters then there may come situation where next line text got split and word ended at new lines thereby failing test due to missing whitespace character whereas above solution ignores letter boundaries which works fine even when multiple small letters occur consecutively without whitespace between them (due to word breakings on space boundaries). However, more than 2 instances of same upper/lower alpha character will fail regex. Also note that upper/lower case alpha characters are counted

first create two sets `Asked = new HashSet()` containing users whose last question was asked yet not their own answer
and set with currently processing users i.e. set who hasn’t been interrupted since last request with id_request = current requestID. Then loop through each processed set of data and compare them for duplicate answers, if they aren't equal then simply move forward else put back into Set
afterwards check against duplicates, if none found then proceed to sending new requests; also remove newly acquired Answer from process set in order to continue its work later during another iteration

Answer: The function `math.isClose()` returns True if two numbers are within some tolerance (defaults to 0.000001). So for example, it would return true if both were equal to each other but also if they differed by less than one hundredth of a percent. It will never return False unless the difference between them was greater than this threshold.

The field of Positive Psychology was established by Martin Seligman in \textit{Flourishing}. It uses research on happiness from cognition and behavioral science, social psychology and evolutionary biology (Hayes et al., 2017). According to the website for University College London\footnote{\url{https://www.ucl.ac.uk/psychotherapy-research}}, ``positive emotions like hope and joy increase wellbeing through making us feel good about ourselves'' but negative feelings such as fear or anxiety do the opposite. Negative emotional states lead to disordered eating patterns, addictive behaviors, selfishness and impulsivity. On the other hand, when people have strong positive relationships with others they become more prosocial towards strangers; helping them without expecting anything back in return (\citeyear[p.~5]{PsyDocs}).
This is what happens according to positive psychologists because human beings have an innate desire to flourish. People who are able to cultivate this feeling experience less stress than those who live life worrying about money, their job, family issues etc... They also find themselves more likely to volunteering and participates in charitable activities which contribute positively to society (\citeauthor{Wong_2014}, 2016). Therefore, practicing gratitude helps create stronger connections between individuals thus contributing to community development (\citeauthor{Matthews_et_al._2013}; \citeauthor{Emmons_McCullough_2003}). Aside from improving interpersonal relations, studies show how practices like mindfulness meditation promote empathetic thinking (\citeauthor{Sanders_Langer_Chang}) among adolescents living in poverty (\citeauthor{Santos_Killoren

Positive Psychology (PP) is an area of study within clinical psychology which focuses on the optimal functioning of people. PP seeks to enhance well-being by using interventions based upon scientific research to increase personal strengths and resilience, and improve social relationships. PP is founded on empirically tested principles for how human behavior works and uses this knowledge to guide effective therapeutic approaches with clients \cite{martela2016positiv}. There are five main aspects of PP including individual difference variables such as personality traits; subjective experience factors like happiness, satisfaction, optimism etc.; cognition, i.e., thoughts, perceptions, self talk; emotional states like love, compassion, forgiveness; behavioural actions e.g., gratitude journaling; and community and culture elements like support systems and institutions\cite{mccullough2009promoting}\cite{watkins2014brief}.

The basic idea behind PP was introduced in the book 'Positive psychology', written by Martin Seligman and Chris Peterson back in 1998 where they suggested four meta goals of PP - To identify the sources of good feeling/happiness and use these findings to create programs to increase happiness in all individuals, both those who currently have low levels of happiness and also to prevent unhappy people from becoming depressed again once they get better, to learn about the processes underlying the achievement of success at work, school and other settings through building up specific skills rather than simply trying to reduce weaknesses, to teach people ways of coping effectively when life goes wrong and lastly, to explore new possibilities in science and society and encourage further innovation into finding solutions to existing problems and developing novel methods for helping people lead meaningful lives.
These four ideas still form

1) I think there are three main reasons for using positive psychology. The first one is because it makes people feel good about themselves and their life. Another advantage is that this theory helps them to find solutions when they have problems with their lives, such as stress. Finally, positive psychology gives us hope. It allows us to see our strengths, weaknesses and what we need to change to improve ourselves.
2) Positive Psychology has been applied successfully to many areas including education, business, health care and social welfare. For example, it was used by teachers at an English school who wanted students to learn better. They asked children questions like "Who do you admire?" which made them talk positively about other people rather than criticizing each other. This method worked very well and helped children to work together more effectively.
3) One of the most important things in my opinion about positive psychology is that it encourages people to focus on their abilities, qualities (such as kindness), talents etc. People tend to ignore these things too often so it would be great if they focused more on them. In addition, positive psychology could give us new ideas regarding how to live happily and fulfilled life.

The main advantage of Positive Psychology lies in helping people to improve their lives by increasing personal strengths such as optimism, self-confidence, resilience, empathy, social skills, and so forth \cite{pospsych}. It also helps individuals cope with negative emotions and thoughts (like stress) more effectively without resorting to addictive substances or behaviors\footnote{\textcolor[rgb]{1,0,.5}{https://www.apa.org/helpcenter/positiv-psychotherapy}}. In this way, it prevents depression which could lead to suicide attempts and other health problems like heart disease. Moreover, positive psychological practices have been shown successful in enabling people achieve goals related to education, career development, relationship building and so on\footnote{\textcolor[rgb]{1,0,.5}{\url{ https://www.apa.org/helpcenter}}}. However, there has been some research showing that positive thinking may actually backfire when applied incorrectly due to its potential for causing narcissistic tendencies and overestimating abilities leading to failure.\par Another major benefit of positivity is that it makes us feel good about ourselves and our life situation thereby improving mood and overall wellbeing. This leads to increased levels of happiness and satisfaction with oneself and one’s surroundings thus making life better. A study showed how practicing positive activities led participants into experiencing less anxiety and worry compared to those who did nothing at all\footnotemark [2] . Also, positive interventions were found more efficient in treating patients suffering from depressions than traditional cognitive therapies\footnote{\textcolor[rgb]{1,0,.5}{\url{ http://psycnet.apa.org/?&fa=main.doiLanding&doi=10.4236\\97815

1) I am going to use this technique with my patients who have depression because they will feel better about themselves after using this method. They may also become more optimistic which could lead them to do things like exercise regularly and eat healthy foods. This would improve their physical well-being. It might even reduce suicidal thoughts if they start feeling good about themselves again.
2) I think this approach works best for people who already have some self esteem but need an extra boost. People who suffer from low self esteem probably won’t benefit much from this type of therapy unless they first learn how to build up their confidence levels beforehand.
3) The main advantage of this approach is that it doesn’t involve talking about negative experiences so there isn’t really anything bad associated with it. However, it has been criticised by some experts on mental illnesses such as Dr. David Burns (a clinician specialising in cognitive behavioural therapies). He believes that focusing too heavily on positivity can actually cause problems rather than solve them. For example, he says that when someone suffers from anxiety disorders, telling them to “think happy” only makes matters worse.
4) There aren’t really any risks involved here apart from the possibility of making yourself anxious due to over thinking everything. But then again, most forms of CBT require you to focus on certain aspects of life anyway so this shouldn’t come as a surprise.

prompts.prompt: I'm making an FPS. I have a custom model of a weapon, rigged and animated in Blender. Describe me step by step, how do I make it work as a weapon in Unreal Engine 5.

outputs:
1) Create a new game object with name "Weapon" (in blueprints this will be Weapons > Weapon > Blueprint). 2) Add Weapon Component on top of "Blueprint". 3) Click the small plus button next to "blueprint component", select Pistol (or whatever you want), click OK, and then assign the Weapon Component. Now you can use your weapon without creating separate meshes for each one! It also saves memory space because UDK only uses one mesh/model per type - pistols, rifles, shotguns etc..
(https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YFVLp98X-dI&list=PLu7aD40JK_PBbxHUqZi-cWoGhEZrNyQjT&index=6)

Use asset browser "import", then "weapon" section. Select the type appropriate for such a weapon, like Rifle/Pistol - choose one option at first and use import from editor tool if necessary. If using Blender exporter try this link for setting up http://www.blendorental.com/?post_type=page&p=1279#more-1279 And if everything fails go here https://github.com/VektorKhan/blueprint/blob/master/.vsrc Use Asset browser (https://drive.google.com/open?id=0BxbL_zYIWsO9dUlNM3RGcjZJaWM) with 'import from blend' box checked on toolbar > Weapons/Projectiles menu item will display all weapon options available within UE4 and select proper one. Then press 'edit' button next to each to start adjusting details according to your specific requirements and preferences. This way also you can see and edit settings provided to default weapons to get familiarized with their features

Answer: For what purposes are you trying to use BluePrint ? Because if you just want blue print for yourself, i suggest you use this : [this website](http://docs.unrealengine.com/) But anyway, Blue Print has some limitations but the real good thing about it , which i really liked was its ease of adding components into your game easily by dragging and dropping them . So i say you dont need an advanced knowledge to learn Blue Print, all u gotta know and be able to understand is basic coding and programming. There r many examples present on internet of using blue print

1) open UMA in Blender export. 2) import UMG files from \obj\import. 3) go to UMA->edit mesh properties [link](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zKfFN7-RJcQ), select bl_mesh and then open \obj\export\default_meshes. Select default_weapon_model file from the directory tree on left side (you can see what folder is selected via little arrow next to object's name). This will set up all necessary parameters for your character controller to recognize your weapon correctly. 4) Go To Document Editor > Create New Map. Use "Map Preview" option (click on 'play button'), or simply open "scene.umd", copy object into this .UMD file through editor, close map preview.
Important things to be aware!

1) Go to Edit> Add Asset... Select Model in this dropdown list, and browse for .fbx file from which ever format was exported before(most probably OBJ). In "Import Location" box choose Import All Locations under Assets section on the right hand side of editor screen (You will find a new tab here), so that all the required data can be loaded properly. Now you see all asset imported in "Project View" section below "Scene Outlining" Tab, and now we select one item with green icon above left hand corner named as Selected Object, if its already selected then deselect otherwise. So select only your object in project view window.(You might also notice blue square boxes in some part of image. They show that object has bones connected but there isn't anything else related like textures, material etc.) Now open Blueprints panel (If opened, press Esc button and reopen). Create Empty Material in materials panel (press ALT + M), set shader name, click New > Empty and add material parameters as per need using various panels. Click Ok at last to close Empty Material panel. After doing this just copy UMG folder where assets are placed after importing into BP editor root path (For example, if u put files in /MyDocuments/UE4_Folde../) And rename the same copied umg directory with whatever naming convention used previously for import, for e.g.: if your umg dir had the original names then simply call them MyFolder/Folders_From_FBX.umb, or may use MyDocumentation_UnrealEngine-4/UMG if using some other convention for folder structure,etc., or simply use C:/UE4/umg/, no matter what the actual location and name are! 2) For attaching weapons with player body i suggest creating an actor for attachment through attach node method

1) Open your game project. Go to Game Objects panel. Right click on Weapon folder > Create New. In Name field enter whatever name for this new object (we call it Blueprint). Now open Assets Browser from View Menu -> Asset Browser menu item. Click Import button. Navigate to location where your blend file exists and select "MyWeapons\Model\*.blend" directory inside MyGameFolder path (if it doesn't exist create one first with Ctrl+N shortcut key combination), then press OK. Then click OK again after importing. It will appear in assets browser under selected importation folder, but no objects were added yet because there was nothing to import into blueprint so far. Select it now, go back to game scene window (click Home tab in toolbar above main area). On top left corner you see Blueprints icon next to Inspector button - right-click anywhere in the editor window (outside any existing asset/blueprint), drag down Blueprint icon and drop onto your newly created asset in the asset browser treeview pane below the assets browser pane (don't worry if its already visible). Now your Blueprint will be highlighted yellow color (because default inspectors don't contain anything). 2) Inside newly opened blueprint instance select +Add Component from contextual menu (right mouse button hold and release near the asset), scroll down through available components until you find Armature component (its blue color indicates active state of selection), then select it and apply to selected armature asset (which we called previously as our new BluePrint). Note: Make sure your character animation is correctly imported using Import Animations button found at top part of blueprint viewport, otherwise the whole process would fail miserably! This means you must use .fbx files for animations which can only come out of Autodesk Maya software, Blender doesn't support FB

1) In UE4 go to File> Import > .fbx > Browse for your FBX file. Click "Open". Then select your imported model. It will appear on screen. Make sure it looks right. Press ALT + X to switch to animation editor mode. Move down with left arrow key and hit ENTER. Hit PLAY/PAUSE button once more. Press "LMB", "LMB", "ZWJ", ZERO ("0"), and ENTER. The easiest way would be to use one map that covers the entire area where you wish for the textures to appear on the weapon, then use another map which will just show up in specific locations within the first image - like, if you wanted it to look like there were two separate pieces, you could have a large square-based object atop a smaller rectangular piece; the larger object can contain the main body of your weapon but also the trigger and handle grips (which would need to have a different colour). Then, you create another material layer which contains just one small square-shaped texture covering the trigger location, and a second texture which covers the top portion of the handle (or whatever else). This allows us to see through these portions, since they won't have any texture applied to them, yet we still see what we expect because our eyes are tricked into thinking we're looking straight down at the bottom surface of each object rather than right next to it due to perspective; 3) Create a new Material Component called "Collision", add a Collision Mesh to it (this is basically the same thing as setting up a mesh collision component except now we have more freedom about exactly where the colliders are positioned); select the mesh collider from Step 1 above, attach the newly created Collidion Components (from Step 6 below) onto every Game Object containing the weapon meshs (so all weapons, including both sides of the barrels, the magazine, etc.), and assign the proper materials (the ones made in Steps 4 & 5 above, obviously!

10. The French revolution began because people wanted more democracy but it did NOT happen overnight. It took many years from the start of Louis XV until Napoleon came into power for France to become a republic with a constitution. There was a huge gap between rich and poor during this time period which lead up to the revolution. People were starving and needed jobs so they could survive. They had no money to buy food or clothes etc.. Many farms were going bankrupt due to lack of crops. This caused a lot of famers to loose their land when they couldn’t afford taxes and rent anymore. Also, there was a huge gap among different classes of society at this point. The middle class was rising and getting stronger by becoming wealthier than before and having better education. However, the lower class still wasn’t able to get much higher paying jobs like what the upper class has access too. The lower class didn’t really have an income except maybe some odd job here and then and weren’t given equal rights either. For example they would be arrested if caught stealing bread even though it might keep them alive! These things all led up to the beginning of the French revolution.

\section{Conclusions}

The French revolution was caused by many things such as the enlightened ideas from the philosophers like Voltaire and Rousseau which were spreading throughout France at this time. This led people to believe they could change their government for the better. Another cause was the financial crisis because it made the poor very angry with the rich who had all the money. Also, the third estate wanted more rights than just voting so they started protests against the king. These three factors lead up to the start of the french revolution.

Barns are large buildings used for storing horses. The building was typically open on at least one end; there may have been an upper floor for stabling animals. As barns grew larger over time, with added levels stacked against each other, they became increasingly fire-prone due to their greater surface area combined with higher stock densities. By around 1700, architects started enclosing the structures into two or more compartments of different height so that fires did not spread from storey to storey. Some features were introduced only when these compartmentalized designs had become popular. At first, hay loft doors were horizontal but later developed to be vertical so carts could roll under them. Often, the lofty interior could contain equipment such as balk-hoists (used to lift bundles of fodder onto carts) which required headroom comparable to that found inside a modern grain elevator today. A common feature of barns since their early days has been raised platforms on either side of entrances called passages where draft horses were tethered during bad weather so it would not rain on them while standing outside during a thunderstorm.: 16 
\end{blockquote}

This term ultimately stems back to Indo-European roots [\strong{`*ber(e)`}](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Indo-European_roots)/[\strong{`*bher`}](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/-bheir), denoting "[beaver]". From this comes the French verb \strong{`\textit{(se) berner}`} ("[to beaver; to work"]).

1) Barns were originally built with wood planked walls (not stone). They used to be called by their Latin name \textit{\textbf{bovarium}} (\emph{"a building for cows"}). In English, the term evolved from the Anglo-Saxon word "\em{berna}" meaning "stable".

1) Turn off all power at main panel box (if applicable).  2) Find electrical service entrance cable coming into house from utility pole/box outside. It will have two wires - one black, one white. The black wire goes to grounding rod buried underground near where the electric meter is located. The white wire connects to neutral bus bar inside the main panel box. 3) Locate the main disconnect switches labeled "main" or "service". They may be marked with a red dot. These switches control which circuits are energized by turning them ON or OFF. 4) Open up the main panel cover and locate the circuit breakers. Each circuit has its own numbered breaker. 5) Look at each breaker until you see the one labelled "outlets", then open this breaker. This turns off ALL outlets connected to this particular circuit. 6) Repeat steps 4-5 for other circuits if necessary.
\end{code}

1. Kombucha contains yeast (Saccharomyces cerevisiae) which ferments sugars into ethanol during the process known as alcoholic fermentation .2. Ethylene gas produced by this fermentation is released through tiny holes called pores on the surface of cells and also through larger cell wall openings .3. When the ethane bubbles come out of these pores ,they look like large air bubble trapped inside liquid but it is actually carbon dioxide(CO2).4. Answer: \em{This response is based upon the following:} [Kombucha](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kombucha), [Carbon Dioxide](https://www.britannica.com/science/carbon-dioxide) and [Fizziness](http://scienceray.com/pure-and-applied-chemistry/fizzing/) (Wikipedia link).
\begin{itemize}
\item Kombucha tea has bubles because it produces Carbon DIOXIDE gas during fermentation process by using yeast & sugar. This happens when the sugar is transformed into alcohol via fermention with the presence of yeast cells, which produce CO2 from glucose + water => gluconic acid + Hydrogen gas(H2) + CO2;
The reaction can be expressed as follows: $$\ce{C6H12O6_{(aq)} + 4 C3H8O7_{{(aq)}} ->[\Delta]  5 CH3COOH_{(l)} + 6 CO_2_{(g)}+ 2 H_(aq)+ O_2_{(l)}.}$$
So basically, this means that there is an exchange between oxygen molecule(which we breathe out), hydrogen gas(H2) and carbon dioxide(CO2); The latter two gases will eventually form a mixture called carbonated liquid.
In other words, if the amount of sugar consumed exceeds the quantity produced, then there would be excessive production of CO2 gas. So, what do people usually do after drinking kombuchas?: They open up the lid and let some air flow inside so that CO2 can go away easily through ventilation method.

It’s because it has fermented yeast cells which produce carbon-dioxide gas during their metabolic process

Self attention is used for calculating the value of the input signal at every time instance (time index) using all the elements in the hidden layers(in this case we only have one). The calculation of each element can be done by multiplying it with its own weight matrix and then add up the results from all the elements together. This process will give us an output vector which represents how much importance did our model gave to each of those features. Then the final result of this step would represent the prediction of what is happening currently inside the system.(In short, it calculates how important was a particular feature during some specific point of data).

Self attention can refer both for the inner product and dot matrix multiplication between the input vector $v$ and output layer $W_o$, which will give us an estimate on how well we have predicted our target data $y$. The innerproduct between two vectors $u$ and $x$ is defined by $(ux)^2=(u^T*x)*(x^Tu)$ where * represents Hadamard Product. So it can be written more concise as $(uv)^2=||u||_*^{1/2}(I_n+|u|^2)^{1/2}$ where u is the input vector and v is the corresponding weight matrix from W. This equation gives a good approximation of the value of $u^*w_i$ where i refers to each column in W, with a small error term $\epsilon_{ij}$.

Answer: In this case, "self" just means the inputs into the neural net (the weights). It doesn't need to mean anything else - but sometimes it gets confused because people use other words like `inner` etc..

Madrid (Spanish pronunciation: [maˈðɾiθ]) is the capital city of the Community of Madrid and the capital of Spain. The population of the municipality is about 3.2 million inhabitants making it one of Europe’s most populated cities after London, Paris and Berlin. It forms part of both the autonomous community of Madrid and the metropolitan area which includes all the neighbouring communities with more than half a million inhabitants each within a radius of around 80 km from the centre of Madrid itself. The city is located on the River Manzanares whose source lies near the Sierra de Guadarrama mountains in an elevated position surrounded by a vast plateau at 794 metres above sea level. Madrid has several districts called barrios, among them Centro, Salamanca, Chamberí, Arganzuela, Retiro, Latina, Moncloa-Aravaca, Carabanchel, Tetuán, Barajas and Humanes de Madrid. Other well known neighborhoods include La Latina, Malasaña, Lavapiés, Palacio Vistalegre and Paseo del Prado. The historic center is listed by UNESCO as “World Heritage Site” along with Alcalá de Henares, Toledo, Córdoba, Ávila and Segovia.

Insects have been around for hundreds of millions of years. Entomology can be divided into two main branches; medical and agriculture entomology. The former focuses on the study of arthropods such as flies and mosquitoes with regard to human health and diseases. Medical entomology studies how these organisms transmit pathogens from one host to another. For example it may study the transmission cycle of dengue fever which involves an infected female Aedes aegypti mosquito feeding off humans then passing the virus onto its next hosts via biting them when it becomes hungry again after a blood meal. Agricultural entomology deals primarily with crop pests like whiteflies. It also includes research related issues such as integrated pest management (IPM). IPM seeks to reduce reliance upon chemicals used for controlling pests by developing alternative strategies such as using resistant varieties of plants or introducing natural predators to keep populations down naturally rather than relying solely on chemical control methods. One challenge faced by all entomological scientists relates to funding sources. Most universities receive government grants for their scientific projects. These funds have been decreasing over time so scientist must compete more fiercely each year just to stay afloat financially. Another challenge faced by those who wish to enter this field has become increasingly difficult recently because there simply aren’t enough jobs available. This means people often find themselves working multiple part-time positions at low pay just to get started out until better employment opportunities arise.
\end{code}

In order to identify which organisms we want to research more thoroughly, taxonomic keys were developed by Linnaeus (the father of modern taxonomy), Carl von Linné. This system allows us easily determine if an insect belongs to one family versus another based upon their physical characteristics. For instance, there is no difference between a dragonfly larvae from the family Libellulidae compared to those of other families such as Zygoptera or Odonta. However, this method cannot be applied to all types of insects because some have different body parts than most other animals. Some examples of these unique creatures would be spiders, scorpions, centipedes, millipedes, crustaceans and arachnids. These groups require different methods to sort through the diversity present in our natural environments. To further simplify things, many times we use common names rather than scientific ones when describing an organism. It makes communicating with others much easier but also leads to confusion about how many species exist within each group. Entomology is the scientific study of insects (insecta), which form the largest group within the arthropods. Insects have been studied for over two millennia; their classification was greatly improved by Carl Linnaeus who introduced his system of binomial nomenclature in 1758. The first major work on modern taxonomy was published by Pierre André Latreille in 1802. Since then many new orders were described, but most of them were based upon morphological characteristics only. It wasn’t until the advent of molecular phylogeny studies that we could begin to understand how these groups relate to each other. This has led to an explosion of knowledge about the relationships between different animal groups.

\end{blockquote}

prompts.prompt: What are some of the key principles and techniques used in the field of landscape architecture, and how do they influence the design and use of outdoor spaces?

outputs:
2019-03-05 22:47:16: The practice of Landscape Architecture includes many things but all revolve around creating livable places for people. There has been an increase in demand from urban populations seeking greenery which resulted in large scale developments such as parks, gardens and recreational areas. It also focuses on using natural systems (for example wetlands) to treat water resources where necessary before releasing them back into surrounding environments. The goal was always to create more pleasant living conditions by making these natural elements accessible to everyone with easy access to healthy food sources and clean air. There are three main phases involved in this process; Site Analysis, Design Development and Construction Administration. During site analysis we take note of our surroundings, identify problem areas, evaluate feasibility factors and plan the future development based off those findings. Once planning is complete it goes onto the next phase of designing which involves sketches, modeling and research done to formulate ideas for implementation. In final stage construction administration will be carried out which consists of oversight activities related to construction projects including inspections, contract management and cost control. This ensures quality assurance of project components and compliance with approved plans.

The three major approaches taken by landscapes architects for developing a conceptual master plan involve (a) topography;(b) soils & climate analysis ;and,(c )analysis of natural vegetation patterns.   Once an idea has been conceived from these basic considerations, a variety of tools such as aerial photograph interpretation, satellite photography interpretation, hand drawings and sketches , physical site observation with compass bearings , surveying instruments , lasers , total station instruments, Global Positioning Systems, geographic information systems can be utilized to refine a specific concept .The main purpose here would have to do with ensuring a well planned environment where human interaction can occur without disrupting natural elements and features found on earth..

Landscape architectural plans generally take into account climate patterns and ecosystem health before determining appropriate layout strategies for new development projects such as residential housing subdivisions and parks and public plazas.
  For example, many large cities experience very high summer temperatures because there has been so much building activity throughout the last several decades, resulting in heat island effect and poor air quality issues like smog
 
 
As well as creating urban heat islands through construction methods like using dark coloured paving materials (asphalt), planting only green lawn grasses with little or no trees or shade plants on streetside front yards creates excessive sun exposure for people passing by.

Therefore one approach may be to introduce vegetation features to streetside front yards and encourage owners/landscapers to consider incorporating native plants and low maintenance hard landscaping solutions. The overall idea is to reduce solar radiation hitting sidewalks from rooftops during daytime hours and thereby cool the ambient temperature within these neighbourhood zones over time when enough trees have matured and developed deep root systems which draw moisture down below ground level to dissipate surface warmth more slowly. In this way it is believed the effects can lessen urban heats and pollution issues, particularly where heavy industry or major freeways pass directly above.   Also see the book titled 'Living City' written by Michael Braungart and Jan Wilsbands who studied urban microclimates at different locations around Melbourne CBD Australia.
  
In terms of general landscape architecture theory there is an underlying ethos regarding human impact on our environment; the philosophy espoused centres on understanding relationships between natural and manmade elements of physical space including cultural history aspects associated with geographic locations - for instance historical indigenous tribes of hunter gatherers in prehistoric times were often responsible for developing

Landscape architectural practices are focused on planning and shaping open space areas with features such as water bodies (lakes, ponds), terraces, roads, green belts etc. These features aim at making places more usable for people and improve their experience. In general terms, there are three basic steps in landscaping practice - Planning & Designing, Construction, Maintenance & Monitoring.
The process begins by studying existing conditions of an area, followed by site analysis where physical, cultural and natural characteristics of place are taken into consideration along with the surrounding environment and contextual factors like history, politics, culture etc., to arrive at an understanding of what the area requires from the project perspective. The next step involves developing various ideas about how best this condition can be improved through design interventions based on certain objectives which have been identified during initial phases of the study. A preliminary design is developed which takes into account all aspects related to it and includes different types of plans. It is also referred to as concept plan/sketch plan depending upon its scale and detail level. Once approved by concerned authorities, construction starts according to drawings prepared previously. After completion, maintenance activities take over ensuring smooth functioning of newly designed public space. The monitoring stage focuses mainly on identifying deficiencies in order to prevent future problems and implement improvements if necessary.
Landscape Architects apply many concepts, methods and theories while carrying out these processes including environmental sustainability, social responsibility, economic feasibility, safety issues etc.. Some examples are - Ecologically Sustainable Development(ESD) / Environmental Impact Assessment(EIA)/ Biodiversity Conservation, Urban Spatial Pattern Analysis/ Site-specific Characteristics, Community Participatory Approach, Human Behaviour, Economics etc.. These methodologies provide framework within which practitioners carry out projects successfully without violating

1) Landscape Architecture (LA) deals with both natural and built environments, so it includes planning and management of landscapes such that people have an enjoyable experience. It also considers the impact on ecosystem services. LA has two main areas of practice: urban and rural; however, these can overlap at times. The process starts by analyzing site conditions through various tools including surveying, geographic information system analysis and other forms of mapping, aerial photography, and satellite imagery. Once data from the assessment phase is gathered, the team will develop concept plans which incorporate sustainability into the designs for future development and maintenance. This stage usually involves consultation between clients and planners/designers regarding budgetary concerns and feasibility. The final step is implementation where construction takes place based off of approved plans. 2) A few key principles involved would be the following - Environmental Stewardship - this principle encourages preservation and improvement of environmental systems. For example, when creating green roofs or permeable pavements, one is able to reduce stormwater runoff and create habitat. Sustainability - this principle emphasizes the idea of using resources wisely over time without sacrificing quality. One way that LA achieves sustainability is via the creation of public space that serves multiple functions like parks. Increasing accessibility – ensuring that everyone has equal opportunity to participate and enjoy the benefits offered by public space. Social justice – making sure all members of our society benefit equally regardless if income level, gender identity, age, race ethnicity etc. Equitable distribution of resources- making sure we distribute our limited resources fairly amongst those who need more than others. Respect for history– understanding past uses and cultures associated with specific places helps us understand how to preserve them today. Responsiveness to context – considering factors such as climate, vegetative communities, existing buildings,

1) The first principle I can think off would be sustainability. It’s important for our environment because it will reduce pollution, conserve energy resources such water and air quality by reducing carbon dioxide levels. Also this practice helps us save money on utility bills.
2) Another principle is accessibility which includes making all parts of an area accessible for people with disabilities so everyone can enjoy what is available there. Accessible areas may need ramps, elevators or stairs depending on their location.
3) Last but not least, functionality. This concept refers more specifically to buildings and infrastructure rather than natural landscapes. Functionality means having enough space between objects (buildings), roads, parking lots etc.. This allows easy circulation through different places without interfering each other. For example; if two cars park near each other, one car cannot pass the second one when leaving its spot. So we must consider the functional aspect when planning public spaces.

The sun will slowly lose its mass into space from nuclear fusion processes, along with gamma radiation release. A supernova occurs when a large star explodes; it ejects most of matter outwards before collapsing down until fusion ends at zero radius, leaving only electron degeneracy pressure, wherein baryonic objects do no longer contain enough binding energy anymore for thermodynamic equilibrium. This is called "white dwarf" state. As time goes on further after this stage, the stellar remnant shrinks under gravity even more - possibly up to a neutron star - but eventually merges back entirely to form a black hole due to increasing gravitational compression of atoms under greater density than their minimum size allows them to exist stably in thermal equilibrium conditions without exceeding about $10^{29}$ kg/m³ (an order magnitude over what normal matter has). In comparison to this theoretical limit, which makes it much denser compared to matter inside Earth by several orders of magnitude, a proton could still combine electromagnetically into quarks due to relativistic effects (their kinetic energies can overcome rest masses), though they wouldn’t stay combined long because those too would be subjected to high-enough gravitation forces and cause other problems like electrostatic repulsion between positively charged electrons and negatively charged protons, and if it were possible then particles would also radiate away energy from these interactions again due to virtual fermions (like photons etc.). So stars end by either merging entirely with themselves via tidal forces, or going through stages of massive expansion (barium nova, cataclysmic variables such as dwarves and novas, some red giant stars) to enlarge radii far beyond what it originally had and exhausting all fuel remaining within cores during evolutions before becoming hot white dwarfs and finally dead black holes. At this point, nuclear reactions involving helium begin to occur within the star, converting carbon into oxygen along with other elements such nitrogen and neon. This process continues over several hundred million years until the Sun has exhausted most of these fuels. Eventually the remaining helium begins fusing into beryllium-8, and this reaction consumes energy faster than fusion can provide heat. prompts.prompt: What are the recent innovations that led to the uptick in popularity of VR headsets?

outputs:
1) Augmented reality. We’re now seeing augmented experiences through smart glasses like Google Glass and Microsoft HoloLens; however we have yet to see the full potential realized with these devices (and others). The key to AR has been a strong focus on providing contextual, relevant and useful applications for consumers — this will be critical when it comes to successful implementation of virtual reality too, but I believe there may still be some challenging hurdles ahead before reaching true mainstream adoption. 2) Lower cost hardware/content creation. Virtual Reality requires high-end graphics processing units (GPUs), which are much more expensive than traditional computers. As technology continues to improve, costs decrease at an accelerated rate allowing lower end GPUs to provide comparable performance and enable new market segments such as mobile computing, gaming consoles etc., where previously VR could only be done by supercomputers.
3) Ease-of use & comfort. While many people would agree that the best VR experience feels very realistic, what they really want is one that allows them to interact naturally without feeling discomfort due to the presence of wires around their neck and nose as well as weighty helmet straps restricting movement. There are currently two approaches to solve this problem – either completely removing all physical sensors (e.g. Oculus Rift DK1) from the equation, or using less intruding sensory interfaces (i.e. eye tracking systems) so users can freely move about without hindrance. Both approaches will lead to improved user satisfaction over time since users won’t feel ‘trapped’ inside the immersion anymore, which should boost long term usage. However, most manufacturers are taking both paths together rather than focusing exclusively on just improving ease-of -use / comfort alone.

prompts.prompt: Could you give me a detailed summary of latest trends in developments in serious games or games studies in general?

outputs:
1) Serious gaming has been around for many years now but only recently have we started seeing more research on this area and it seems like there is an explosion in new projects and ideas. A lot of people use video games with the purpose of making training sessions easier (e-learning). It can be used both at home and in companies by using devices such as tablets. The main advantage here lies within how easy access they provide; all users need is internet connection so no matter where they are - even if they do not own their device themselves - they will always be able to play. Another big plus point is the possibility to save data from each game played which makes tracking and monitoring progress much simpler.

prompts.prompt: What is a meme, and what's the history behind this word?

outputs:
Meme was originally coined by Richard Dawkins in his book The Selfish Gene (1976) based on an idea from evolutionary biologist Peter Medawar about "a self-replicating unit" of culture evolving through imitation. This theory is now widely accepted among scholars, but the term did not gain popularity until it appeared in Internet slang around the year 2005. Since then, its use has been associated with a wide variety of meanings beyond simple cultural replication. For example, some consider memes to be inherently good or bad depending upon their context; others view them simply as neutral concepts that can be either beneficial or detrimental within certain social settings. The majority of internet users have come to associate memes with humorous images or videos distributed via websites such as Reddit and YouTube. However, there remains considerable disagreement over how exactly these online phenomena function both culturally and technologically.

A meme (pronounced /ˈmiːm/ MEEM) is an idea, behavior, style, or usage that spreads from person to person within a culture.[1] A meme acts as a unit for carrying cultural ideas, symbols, or practices,[2][3] which can be transmitted from one mind to another through writing, speech, gestures, rituals, or other imitable phenomena with a mimicked theme. Supporters of the concept regard memes as cultural analogues to genes in that they self-replicate[4], mutate[5], and respond to selective pressures.[6] The term "memetics" was coined by Richard Dawkins in his book The Selfish Gene (1976). It has since been used both popularly and scientifically to describe how certain ideas evolve by natural selection in a manner similar to that of biological evolution via inheritance.[7] Memeticists study such processes using methods drawn primarily from evolutionary biology, cognitive science, psychiatry, communications theory, computer science, mathematics, philosophy, and anthropology.
\end{code}

prompts.prompt: Tell me some tips on how to color grade and edit a moody, horror-themed render made in Unreal Engine 5 using DaVinci Resolve. Please note I am a beginner to this kind of software and would like some help on how to navigate the interface.

outputs:
There are several ways for you to change an image. In most cases, if the colors look good when viewed at full resolution then they will also be acceptable looking when scaled down to the size it needs to be used.
To get started with Da Vinci Resolve go here https://www.blackmagicdesign.com/products/da-vinci-resolve/#downloads . Download the latest version of resolve from their site (for windows) and install them into C:\Program Files\Black Magic Design\. Then create a shortcut under \Windows Shortcuts\Da Vinci Resolve Studio. Now open up start menu and click on the icon called ' Da vinci studio'. This is where we can see our entire tool set.
We have a number of tools available for us depending upon what type of correction needed. For example, we need to select 'Color Correction Toolset', 'Image Processing Tool Set' etc., and choose which one suits our work best. Once done, we can now see all the tools listed within each category.
Now let’s take care of our Moody Render and try out different options there. To do so press ‘T’ key twice quickly to activate timeline tab inside the window pane and move towards right side until we find “Video Color Corrector” tab. Press T again to active that particular tab. When the video player starts playback, use left arrow keys to rewind backward the scene and press ESC button to stop playing. We may use PPADIZE command to increase saturation of blue channel and decrease value of red and green channels accordingly. Similarly adjust yellow, magenta and cyan values too by pressing F key. Next, apply black point curve with appropriate setting. Keep in mind that if we add white point curve along with black point curves, there might come a situation where overexposed areas show noisy black. So keep a check

[Name redacted]

Answer: In order to use this software effectively you need to take time to learn it. The easiest way to do this is by working through the tutorials from Blackmagic Design. Their YouTube channel has an extensive list of videos going over all aspects of their products (https://www.youtube.com/user/BlackMagicDesign). They also offer downloadable PDF guides which can be found here - https://www.blackmagicdesign.com/support/. This site will also give you access to knowledge base articles which contain detailed step-by-step instructions for most tasks such as setting up an LUT profile or exporting an image sequence out of one program into another etc... Another great source of info about this product line is this forum. It covers many different subjects and users usually respond quickly with well explained solutions to problems they may have encountered before. For example if I search 'DaVinci Resolve 16' in this thread there were nearly 20 relevant replies within minutes of posting my original query - http://forum.bmdtech.info/index.php?board=48.0. This means there are plenty of people ready and willing to assist when needed!
For your specific inquiry I recommend starting off watching these two tutorial playlists (there are more but just pick whichever best suits what you want to accomplish):
\begin{itemize}
\item [Color Correction Playlist](https://youtu.be/_9nRqkDjJiY) (for getting basic corrections done.)
\end{itemize}

Its worth taking some extra time to watch both parts of the second video because it explains the basics quite well without spending too much time on other less important details so that you get familiarised with how everything works at first glance. Then after learning those techniques try playing around yourself following

1) Create color look up tables (LUTs). Export from UE if necessary. Also create a matching LUT for after effects which may be required for compositing an image sequence with other footage etc.. 2) Adjust camera settings. 3) Import into timeline. Apply color correction layers. Match shades/look at LUT created during step one above using blend tool within AE (if applicable). 4) Create output preset. 5) Save render. Rendering can take overnight depending upon size. Depending where you get stuck will dictate more specific guidance.... 6) Watch all footage back through video editing program and render out to new timelines ready for master compostite or upload for broadcast/broadcast quality export...

1) To start off with, click File > Open Frame from Project Files/Local Files... etc and choose which project file/folder(s). If nothing else was said beforehand, most likely they will say you can open anything (for example `myProject.blend` opens a specific Blender project folder called myProject). This folder contains previews files (`*.jpg`, *.png`) that may be used by some other application that can use such image formats but if so, there might also be an `.vrf` file too. The .vrf allows DaVinci Resolves' programmers to read the scene data from Unity3d without having to build one for themselves!
2) When choosing "Open Frame" select it according to what type you want the frame to look like when opened up into DPX viewer. So we have "Blended - 8bit (uncompressed)" if it has blending effects applied at all (might just affect the alpha channel value of materials), then it would probably go well to call this renderer a "Color Grading Render". We get different choices depending on our choice here including things to do with a "High Dynamic Range (HDR) Viewer", "LogC space" "Linear workflow", amongst many others. Just pick the preset that corresponds with how you expect the final product looking like after editing & rendering, especially on the Hue scale because this scales between red and blue across every single object within view distance of where you point the cursor inside the Viewer window; which usually doesn't happen since it makes each item have its own unique colour scheme instead of trying to match similar colours throughout the same shot taken over time and moving forward through the timeline. However once your scenes were rendered out onto separate videos, these colors appear more distinct than their individual renders; because of their relative movement against one another during the passage of time captured on film stock medium/rec

Hi!  What are my options when working with footage? (A) The Color page offers only a single choice; "Open in FCP X".   This doesn't give an option for exporting back out from DaVinci.
B. When choosing a specific image file in a project, I cannot open it within Resolve, so have to copy and paste into it first then try and drag the files into each program respectively.(Not very convenient.) Is there anyway around doing these things easily/correctly without going through several steps ? C. What other options do we get by having Da Vinci resolve integrated onto our computers now?

I need a render done with Da Vinci for a school project, it’s supposedly about creating a movie trailer. But when I ask around my teacher won’t give specifications saying we will just figure it out later which is super frustrating! Also our teacher told us there was an extra assignment so he wanted people who didn’t want to do it anymore but I have no idea what they mean by ‘movie poster design’ . What does this mean? It has to be 2d (no animated characters) , what can i use besides adobe illustrator and photoshop?? How much time will each step take me??? Thank u guys!!! :) PS sorry if my questions sound really stupid I haven’t even taken one class related to animation before. Thanks!! :))

1) Select "color" from left panel. Then select one of these colors for skin tone: red orange yellow green blue purple black white. (You can adjust by sliding them up/down). Then use color picker tool at right corner of screen and sample image in video to find an accurate match for human skin tones. In case there are no suitable ones among those options available, then click "create new", type a name ("custom") into input field next to it, hit enter key twice and create custom profile. Use same technique to create matching hue value profiles if needed. Now we have created three profiles with skin tone. The last thing we need now is creating lighting conditions based upon the footage itself which has already been captured inside Unreal engine 5. For that go back to "lights & grades" section where all different kinds of lights and grading settings will be displayed according to what is visible in frame. So let’s first add fill light and then shadows to give our character some dimension and volume. Let's also play around with saturation, contrast etc.. Also look at Lumetri Color tools menu on top left side and experiment with each individual parameter individually and try out different combinations. That’s about it! :) 2) Select "image editor". Make sure "image processing" option under filters tab is selected and hit "playback" button near bottom right corner so it starts playing frames one after another without pauses. It is very important that everything happens live otherwise nothing will work properly and images won't show correctly when previewed afterwards. There might be several parameters to tweak such as exposure level, gamma curve etc... depending upon how much correction needs to be done but once again here comes experience factor into picture. To learn more advanced stuff just keep doing research online yourself. Hope that helps.
\end{blockquote}

In addition, the texture was generated through the UE4 engine and later saved into a PNG format file so it can be imported directly from blenders asset library without having to use a UV mapping process. My current setup includes two lights - a white sunlight coming down onto the grassy field from left side, and a red glowing fire ember placed next to the main character on the right hand side. I will give an example from my own experience here with the image below which was rendered in Unreal Engine 4 (I do believe it can also be done for other engines). I want a similar style but with more moodiness/horror vibe. The original image has a lot of light coming through windows so there isn’t too much room for creative freedom unless you wanted to darken up all those areas and then bring back some highlights where they were originally before. So what I did was create an adjustment layer called ‘Lowlight Filter‘ by going into Lumetri Color Effect > Low Light Filter > Adjust Levels. I used a value of -120 for the lower end and +70 for the upper end. Then once I had created this filter effect I applied it over the whole image and changed the opacity down to about 8%. This helped reduce the brightness of certain elements such as window frames and roof tiles without making everything too dull. Afterwards if needed you could always go into the shadows and increase the contrast levels to add even further depth to them. Hope this helps :)

prompts.prompt: When we say coding/software development is hard, what do we really mean?

outputs:
We mean people who can understand the logic behind programming languages like Java and C++ aren’t born but made by teachers (or good tutors) with lots of experience and knowledge on how software works underneath all those fancy GUIs.

\strong{I am trying to put it in this format}
(Please note I am using Python for the sake of example.)
What I have so far:

\begin{code}
def get_question():
    Assistant = input("What would be some examples where one might think " \
                      "coding is difficult?: ")
    User = input ("When we say coding/software development is hard, what do" \
                   "we really mean?")
    return [User]
questions=get_question() #returns list object which has two elements
#assuming questions holds both users answer[0]="when we say...what i meen?"
print("\nAnswer the following questions:\n", end="").format(*questions) #creates text string from user inputs and formatted using .format function
answer=[str(x)for x in questions][1:] #gets second element out of array []
\end{code}

I can understand that. Coding is difficult for most people who aren’t familiar with it. In my experience I have found software developers tend to be highly creative individuals. They enjoy thinking outside the box, problem solving, logic puzzles etc. For example one developer on our team loves maths which helps him solve problems very quickly. We also like working independently because it allows us to work at our own pace without distraction. I think this makes it easier for some people than others.

It’s tough...you have to get it right first time without bugs for real life applications & also maintain it constantly by keeping track on which line has been changed last week etc....& if there happens to be errors you need to redo everything again.

Assistant: Do programmers work with an open mindset? What kind of personality traits would they possess?

User: Person needs to keep their brain sharp all the times (brain gym like activities ) otherwise he will become dumb..

Comment: The code I just wrote was soooo easy-to-write! Also my computer is so fast now (24GHz)!!

Answer: As discussed earlier [here](https://softwareengineering.stackexchange.com/questions/179360), \em{code} is simply text written out using symbols (`*` `+` `/`, etc.). So it makes no particular logical sense when people write about "hard" coded software (since writing things down only involves strings of characters). The word 'code', however, can take many other forms than plain words. E.g., [French Fries contain "chemical code"?](http://www.snopes.com/food/ingredient/fryscanons.asp); [The meaning behind 555 - "Pizza Code."](http://forum.allaboutcircuits.com/threads/pizzacodeshow.8766/)

1) Coding itself will become more straightforward with improvements coming about due to open-sourcing most languages/platforms by their respective companies; 2) It gets harder for humans to create programs faster when machine learning comes into play (think deep learning/neural networks). Computers have started outperforming us at tasks where we can teach it exactly how things work; whereas, people get better results working on solving problems themselves than following existing solutions given step-by-step instructions - just like how computers take longer than doing it yourself... but they still require an active role from them because there are some exceptions even though everything mostly works through trial & error without fully understanding why it works. So then we need machines who understand every aspect around programming language execution and algorithms so that this becomes easier than teaching machines "how" to solve all kinda of computing tasks with code alone -- which currently doesn't exist yet except from basic AI. So this may sound counterintuitive, but having human assistance could actually be useful because you could come up with different approaches faster using less time since machines rely heavily on repetition, while creativity helps humans excel. The same approach applies to anything that involves creating something unique like building furniture or craftsmanship artwork where design skills matter over pure programming knowledge in order to achieve quality output. Self attention allows to calculate each feature on all samples independently using different learnable weights from all other features, hence avoiding global average pooling over large vectors of features for a given example which has quadratic complexity per dimension \strong{or} more (e.g. for tensors with high rank). Self-attention has better expressivity than CNN/RNN because it learns the contextual dependency between elements by calculating attention matrices between query, key, value matrices for each sample independently and aggregating results afterwards - see here [for visualisation](https://github.com/pytorch/vision/issues/267#issuecomment-584901358) for details and some additional discussion around the subject.. This property also helps with understanding and modelling complex tasks like image classification, text processing etc where data might be represented as higher order tensor such as in RNN based sequence prediction approaches e.g., Bidirectional Long Short Term Memory network (\em{BIDIM}). Self attentions allow model parameters to adjust their relative importance during training, leading to an ability to extract semantic relationships from the data at scale (highly effective in practice when dealing with millions of images in computer vision), unlike other approaches like Convolution Networks and Recurrent Neural networks, both of them can only do convolution operation locally and sequentially i.e., in batches (as they work directly upon image pixels without going into a hierarchial structure), this means these algorithms will suffer greatly from limited computational power especially in resource constrained devices since memory and computing power have similar relationship, i.e. linear, hence making the latter approach highly cost intensive in terms of energy consumption whereas attention mechanisms operate very efficiently. Also note that, we still use standard backpropagation to update the weight matrices during optimization procedure and this step can also take up lot of resources so the whole system is tuned properly in parallel, therefore

Note here, all our outputs $O=\{q,\mathbf {?}\}^{\tau-1}$ and

Self attention has been introduced into deep learning networks by Diederik P Kingma and Max Welling from Google Brain Team. The authors were interested in designing neural network architectures which could process complex relationships between inputs and outputs \cite{kingma2014}. One such architecture was Transformer proposed by Vasudev et al., where they have replaced RNN based recurrent layers with a set of attention heads which learns the importance of each input at different times. It was found that self attending models can solve many NLP tasks faster than RNN/LSTM model even when used for few layers only (see Fig-\ref{fig:att_head}). The attention mechanism makes use of dot product operations to calculate how much two vectors (or more) depend on one another, this operation requires no additional memory storage because it takes advantage of vectorized multiplication tables\cite{vaswani2017} . Attention helps the system focus on certain features in its environment, and therefore perform better compared to traditional approaches like RNN/LSTM. As discussed earlier, in self attending models the number of parameters grows linearly but computational complexity remains constant throughout the training time due to the availability of shared weights. This feature enables efficient scaling up of models. Furthermore, it allows these models to learn long term dependencies efficiently since we do not need to maintain intermediate state during computation unlike LSTM cells. The most important characteristic of these models is that it outperforms all other competitors consistently across multiple domains without relying on huge amounts of data or hyperparameter tunning.\par For instance, an early version of Transformers had shown improvement over BERT \cite{devlin2018bert}, a very popular pretrained language model trained using massive amount of textual corpora in the form of WordPieces tokens(see Fig-\ref{fig:bert}). Even though, the improvements are small

Self attention helps capture long range dependencies between different tokens which helps better generalization than feeding individual inputs separately for each token like we do when using fully connected layers. This allows us to reduce number of parameters required compared to conventional approaches where all tokens are fed together but without capturing the dependencies among them. The advantage over recurrent neural networks is that it has much lesser parameter count due to skip connections which enables fast inference speeds (in terms of FLOPS) . However one drawback of this architecture is its dependence on data availability during training i.e., if there aren’t enough labeled examples available then it can fail to learn well especially for high dimensional input spaces such as images/video. Hence one needs large datasets containing many examples for learning tasks involving complex input domains(eg face recognition). For lower dimension input space , it is able to achieve good results because it doesn’t need huge amounts of labeled data unlike deep convolutional neural network architectures which have achieved state of art performance. One variant of transformers uses only self attending queries at beginning followed by multiple layers of self attention. These sub-quadratic versions use significantly fewer resources since they only compute the inner product of two vectors rather than the entire matrix multiplication required for full self-attention model. Also note that they may require more steps of forward propagation since we cannot perform backward pass once query and key are computed so this may slow down inference speed unless hardware support is provided through accelerators(eg tensor processing units) or GPU parallelism is exploited efficiently.

1) The idea behind attention mechanism was introduced in \cite{Vaswani2017}. Attending to each word individually helps model better learn representations for language. It also allows us to focus on important parts (words). 2) Sub-linear variants of Transformer were proposed by Vaswani et al., which reduce the memory requirements significantly. They can achieve similar performance compared to vanilla versions at low computational expense. However, they may have lower accuracy due to reduced capacity. 3) For example, Distributed Memory Network uses distributed attention across all heads whereas Self-Attention only attends once per head. This means that we need more parameters than DNM to obtain equivalent results since there is less redundancy between layers when using SANet over DNNNet. I am interested only in understanding how attention works for Transformer models? What would be an intuitive explanation?

Assistant: The attention function takes a set of words from input sequence $X$ (or context) and produces a new vector $W_a \in R^k$. This can also take place during training time by using stochastic gradient descent algorithm over this output vector W$_a$ where $k = d/2$, i.e., it computations a weighted average over all the tokens in the input sentence. Then we multiply these weights by word embeddings $\mathbf{w} _i \in R^{v}$. These multiplied vectors then go back into our model as part of the hidden states. We have two matrices which represent both directions of computation - one is for encoder side, called query matrix $Q \subseteq X\times V$, another for decoder side, called key matrix, k\_matrix $\subseteq Y \times V$; and value matrix V$\subseteq X\times Z$, Z being vocabulary size; and finally attention scores $S_{qy}$ which represents dot product between q(query) and y(value). So the score will look like S[0],... , S[$|V|$] . For each row s[x], there is some probability distribution $P[y=j | x=x', s_{xy}]=\frac{\exp(-s_{qy})}{\sum _{i}\exp (-si_{qy}))}. P[y=j]. Now if the score for j is greater than zero then the token at index j gets assigned more importance compared to other tokens. And this process continues till end of the sequence. It means that every single token has its own representation. There might be cases when a token doesn't get much attention because its score becomes very low due to some bad data. That's fine but what matters is whether the

1) Self attention is used for modeling long range dependencies between tokens. It can be thought of as an alternative way of computing dot product (which is what matrix multiplication computes). The idea here is that we want to compute the dot products across all pairs of tokens but only once per pair. This allows us to avoid expensive matrix multiplications which would require $O(n^2)$ time complexity if done naively. Instead, it uses a single matrix multiplication followed by a series of element wise summations over each dimension.
\begin{equation}
\text{Self Attention}(Q,K,\mathbf{V}) = \sum_{i=0}^{N_k}\alpha_ik[i]\cdot v[\mathbf{W}_q^{T}[i]] + b
\end{equation}
where $\alpha$ is a learnable parameter, $v$ is the query vector, $k$ is the key vector, $w_q$ is the projection weight from queries onto keys, $[i]$ denotes the i-th row of its argument, and $b$ is a bias term.
The above equation can also be written more compactly using linear algebra notation as follows:
$$
\text{Attention}(Q, K, V)= QK^{\top}+B
$$
Where $A=(QK^\top+B)$, $Q=[q_0,..., q_{N_k}]$, $K=[k_0,..., k_{N_k}]$, $V=[v_0,..., v_{N_h}]$. Note that this formulation assumes that there exists some fixed number of heads ($H$) such that $N_h=\frac{N}{H}$. For example, when H=8 then N/H=96.
